overview: Job explores the problem of suffering through the story of a righteous man who loses everything. His debates with friends and encounter with God reveal that we can trust God even when we don't understand.

verses.text: Naked I came from my mother's womb, and naked shall I return. The LORD gave, and the LORD has taken away; blessed be the name of the LORD.
For I know that my Redeemer lives, and at the last he will stand upon the earth. And after my skin has been thus destroyed, yet in my flesh I shall see God.
I had heard of you by the hearing of the ear, but now my eye sees you.
Though he slay me, I will hope in him.

passages.title: The Heavenly Council
passages.summary: Satan challenges Job's integrity, and God permits testing. Job loses everything but refuses to curse God.

passages.title: God Speaks from the Whirlwind
passages.summary: God finally responds—not by explaining why, but by revealing His wisdom and power through creation's wonders.

passages.title: Job's Restoration
passages.summary: Job repents of demanding answers and is restored with double his former blessings. His encounter with God proved sufficient.

facts.text: Job is likely one of the oldest books in the Bible, possibly from the patriarchal period, dealing with timeless questions of suffering.
Job's three friends spoke much truth about God, yet God rebuked them because they misapplied truth to Job's situation.
God never explains to Job why he suffered. Instead, He reveals Himself—and that proves to be enough.
James 5:11 points to Job as an example of perseverance and God's compassionate purpose in allowing trials.

figures.name: Job
figures.description: A wealthy, righteous man who lost everything yet maintained his integrity. He demanded answers from God but found God's presence sufficient.

figures.name: Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar
figures.description: Job's three friends who came to comfort but ended up accusing him, wrongly assuming his suffering proved hidden sin.

figures.name: Elihu
figures.description: A younger man who spoke after the three friends, offering some true insights about God's purposes in suffering.

videos.title: Job Overview
videos.description: The Bible Project explores this profound book about suffering and trust in God.
